title: A uniform ladder

children.value:
A uniform ladder AB of mass 
$\vari{m}$
 rests in equilibrium. A is in contact with a smooth vertical wall and B in contact with a rough horizonal floor. The ladder lies in a vertical plane perpendicular to the wall and makes an acute angle 
$\vari{\alpha }$
 to the horizontal. A horizontal force 
$\vari{P}$
 is applied to the ladder in a direction away from and perpendicular to the wall. This force acts at the point one quarter of the way up the ladder.

answer.value:
$\displaystyle N\s {A} = \frac{1}{2}mg\cot {\alpha } - \frac{1}{4}P $

We can find the reaction force $\vari{N\s {B}}$ at B by resolving vertically on the ladder.

$\displaystyle N\s {B} = mg $

children.value:
Find, in terms of 
$\vari{P}$
, 
$\vari{m}$
 and 
$\vari{\alpha }$
 the magnitudes of the normal reactions at A and B (
$\vari{N\s {A}}$
 and 
$\vari{N\s {B}}$
 respectively)

Show that the frictional force on the ladder at B has magnitude 
$\frac{3}{4}P+\frac{1}{2}mg\cot (\alpha )$

If the coefficient of friction between the ladder and the floor at B is 
$\vari{\mu }$
, the value of 
$\vari{P}$
 is gradually increased from zero. Find how equilibrium will be broken in the following cases

answer.value:
If 
$\mu = \cot {\alpha }$
, then 
$\mu < \mu \s {crit}$
 so equilibrium will be broken by the ladder sliding.

If 
$\mu = 4\cot {\alpha }$
, then 
$\mu > \mu \s {crit}$
 so equilibrium will be broken by the ladder toppling.
